title: /dev: Diving into Champion Bios - Nexus

embed.description: Hello narrative friends. With Pyke's imminent release into the watery wild, Scathlocke and I thought it'd be a good time to dive into a question narrative gets pinged on a lot-champion bios.

body: A new lore related Nexus article.

replies.body:
So, Nautilus is now just a bumbling superstitious idiot who wants people to tip the sea some coins for good luck.

I'm not a fan. It seems to me a dull and boring character motivation, but the deeper problem is that Riot felt the need to explain his motivation at all.  Riot's writers seem to think they have to humanise every character, no matter how inhuman, just to get people to like them. It's an insult to intelligence. I prefer beings like Nautilus to be more than human - unfathomable in their goals. Far too many of League's backstories are now:

"X was once an ordinary man, who loved to do Y. One day, unfortunate incident Z happened to him, and he was transformed into the inhuman creature known as N" (who is basically just an ordinary human with normal human motivations who looks a bit weird and has supernatural powers.)

Seriously, Riot, try to create some genuinely non-human characters. Don't try to humanise them, don't try to explain them, just describe their mysteries in a compelling way. Think Lovecraft.

This was always Nautilus though, he was always a man, a deep sea diver, left to die by his crew. If anything this lore just embellishes what was already there. It's basically an updated retelling of the Nautilus we'd always known before, given a decent coat of extra story context for good measure. I don't see anything wrong with this.

> [{quoted}](name=Sharjo,realm=EUW,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=ARysWkMM,comment-id=00000000,timestamp=2018-05-29T16:48:20.236+0000)

It's basically an updated retelling of the Nautilus we'd always known before, given a decent coat of extra story context for good measure. I don't see anything wrong with this.

Just because Nautilus's story has always been that way, doesn't make it good. My point was that the narrative team had an opportunity to give Nautilus a unique flavour in the Runeterran universe, but instead went for something utterly formulaic.

I suppose Riot don't have to try to come up with compelling stories, though, given how most League fans are young kids raised on superhero movies, and therefore undiscerning in their story tastes.

At the price of potentially alienating the people who liked Nautilus's original theme? Which is a lot of people?

Nautilus has always been about a few specific things: forever pushing forward, despite the difficulties, a desire for revenge on some old crime that's long forgotten, and the terror of the deep ocean. That second part has always been something critical to his character, and what mad him more than just a force of nature. It also adds further in to the whole "human capacity for greatness" thing League has going as a general theme; Runeterra's a human dominated planet, it kinda makes sense that many of the champions who look pretty weird were once human, or a result of humans. It shows how humans are strong enough to handle such powers, while also being able to show how that can go wrong. It also helps put the true non-humans in to a greater context; this is the stuff that isn't human and humans either have to deal with, or could never even match. 

Personally I think if they were gonna make a true, inhuman, deepsea creature, they should make a deep sea monster champion; a leviathan of incredible power or something. Nautilus shows just how much the deep ocean can change someone, while also showing that even through all that, the human beneath the armour endures, to an extent.

As much as it sickens me to say, I dont think Nebula is entirely wrong at the core of their argument. Fans can and do attach themselves to aspects from old lore that are just utterly bad and extremely shallow. As there are plenty of champions who would work more cohesively if their entire narrative was revised in favour of something more refreshing. Also the Narrative discipline shouldn't be afraid to attempt exploring new grounds on old lore, there is plenty of interesting opportunities to fulfill a character with new perspectives. Neither should the community be so paranoid at the prospects of such possible changes occurring as well.

However, since it was specifically made to ask what audience's wanted/hoped for a Nautilus. Its obvious his lore would be settled with something still very familiar to his old lore. Because of the response we get what was asked for.

Making him angry all the time for people not throwing money into the ocean makes him seem silly and it detracts from the listless despair that characterizes him. Nautilus has almost always been devoid of most emotions other than revenge, which is why when his revenge failed he was just aimlessly wandering the oceans. It added to his inhumanity, it made him seem like the mystery that consumed him may be trying to emulate his human nature, but not being good at grasping onto emotions, so it defaults to indifference. Nautilus has always been a bit of an unknown, and now having him be this angry thing that will sink your ship is just not who he is.
I mean, that's exactly what the Nautilus fans asked for. Isn't it good people got what they wanted?

It's not what Nautilus fans asked for. No one asked for him to be fixated on wanting people to give the sea money. But it doesn't matter. League fans will learn to love this new lore, like they end up loving all League lore, and anyone capable of critical thinking will be flamed and downvoted into oblivion.
Implying this opinion is objectively correct

> [{quoted}](name=AphidMan,realm=EUW,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=ARysWkMM,comment-id=000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2018-05-29T19:24:43.925+0000)
>
> Implying this opinion is objectively correct

It is though. Storytelling is not as subjective as you think it is. There is a clear hierarchy of good ideas and bad ones. It's why Citizen Kane is consistently rated as one of the best movies, and The Room is consistently rated as the worst. But most of the people on these boards are kids with the attention spans of gnats, so arguing this point is useless, and will only result in vindictive downvotes.

It's still your opinion and your opinion only (which may or may not be shared by a varying amount of like-minded people).
You are just overreaching with the comparison of two far different movies, both in quality and content.
We're not talking about the difference between Gone with the Wind and Fifty Shades of Grey.

> [{quoted}](name=AphidMan,realm=EUW,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=ARysWkMM,comment-id=00000000000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2018-05-29T22:10:04.464+0000)

> We're not talking about the difference between Gone with the Wind and Fifty Shades of Grey.

A man wanting people to pay the sea money is an objectively boring plot point. It has no depth, no substance, no sense behind it. You can hide behind the "storytelling is subjective" canard all you want - indeed, it is because of people like you that the narrative team don't need to put much effort into their stories. Why bother to create a story that makes sense when you and the other adoring fans will just defend any flaws as "subjective"? 

If Nautilus turned out to be Kanye West who donned the suit because a space dinosaur flew into his skull and told him "tomatoes want to have sex with you", would the quality of such a story be subjective too? I'm sure you'd agree it'd make for an objectively terrible development.

Equally, while Nautilus' new lore is not quite as bad as that, the fact remains that it could have been developed into something far, far richer, something that actually had internal coherence, and satisfied the three levels of conflict; something that wasn't as trivial as wanting people to throw coins into the sea, something that wasn't as meaningless as a man condemned by fate into a mindless walking husk, something that wasn't as mundane as demanding a tithe be paid. How about some subtlety, subtext, reversal, subversion, sacrifice, pathos, twists, turns, foreshadowing, symbolism, mystery, irony - y'know, things that give stories objective value?

To make myself clear, i'm not attacking your opinion or your take on Nautilus lore. It's your idea and i'm not invalidating your points, i'm just pointing out that you are not necessarily right just on the basis of thinking yourself to be right.
The Room is rated as one of the worst movies for more reasons than storytelling...

I mostly agree with you, except for Nautilus' weird fixation with the ocean's tithe.
I think it would have been a much more compelling and tragic story if his motivation was simply seeking revenge against people he had forgotten.

{{champion:432}} comes closest to what you want. Bard has no motives, he has no reason, but he serves a purpose. In his teaser people are dying, but he doesn't care, he just fullfills his purpose by protecting and collecting destructive magical artifacts in order to preserve the universe. He's not true horror lovecraft tier, but builds of a similiar concept, that the universe and the "higher ups" don't care about humanity.

Sounds about right- though one of the comments on that link made me realize something-

> Why is Nautilus evil now? 

He's not **evil**, if anything he's something of a force of **law**. 
A revamped bio does not undo any and all mentions of the character. Unless it's specifically mentioned, Nautilus still does things like help fight off the army in the Harrowing to save people. He's not evil nor does he act out of malice- he goes about ensuring people pay a tithe because to do otherwise is to sacrifice innocent lives to the sea.

> [{quoted}](name=Love and Peace V,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=ARysWkMM,comment-id=0001,timestamp=2018-05-29T17:13:27.282+0000)

He's not evil nor does he act out of malice- he goes about ensuring people pay a tithe because to do otherwise is to sacrifice innocent lives to the sea.

And how does he make them pay the tithe? He can't come to the surface and beseech the ships to chuck money overboard because he physically cannot come to the water's surface without walking to shore. His options are a) sink the ship, or b) ignore the ship. Seeing as he's now driven by anger at people who don't pay the tithe, he can't possibly have any way to make them pay before he sinks their ship. It's an absolutely stupid motivation that makes him come across as an evil ship sinker.

> And how does he make them pay the tithe?

By sinking the ships that don't presumably. It only takes a few survivors managing to return to society screaming about the monster sinking ships before the idea gets across. Alternatively, captains who dismiss paying the tithes and never being seen again along with their ships is a message all in itself.


> Seeing as he's now driven by anger at people who don't pay the tithe, he can't possibly have any way to make them pay before he sinks their ship.

They throw a coin overboard into the water- where he happens to be. He can still see whether a coin was tossed into the waters?
Or for a less literal answer, given that he's now some sort of magical walking water-being, there's a certain set of inherent magical abilities that are assumed to be part of his character. For example, no longer needing to breath, at all. Likewise in his given (magically) appointed role of tithe-collector- it can be assumed he simply knows which ships have this protection and which do not. And you do not need to specifically be told the latter anymore than the former.

There's this odd trend nowadays that fiction needs to inherently lay out every given bit of information and I frankly don't get it. It's a written work- you are *meant* to fill in the gaps with your own imagination. That's the *point* of the medium.

First of all, you're missing my points. I was asking _how does he make ships pay the tithe before sinking them?_ He comes across as an evil asshole if he's just willy nilly sinking ships who are either unaware of an ancient tithe paying practice, or even if they don't pay a tithe when he's immediately beneath them. How is a ship supposed to know when to properly pay a tithe? 
Also, he's not "making a ship" pay the tithe by sinking them, that's counter-productive to the argument I was making. Nautilus supposedly wants ships to pay a tithe or he sinks them. He's got physically no way to request the tithe from them, so his only option is to sink them. It'd be like a toll booth with a road that goes around it sending you a fine for $100 because you didn't pay the toll.
And in regards to this potential "magical ability to detect if people have paid a tithe," come on now. Did you listen to yourself or even read ANY of Nautilus' lore? He was presumably consumed by something unknown and eldritch in the oceans. The only thing he remembers is that his old captain didn't pay a tithe before sending him to inky waters, so assuming that he's got some magic ability to detect when people are being cheapskates is ridiculous, even for fantasy writing standards. We don't have any reason to believe that whatever eldritch thing he is now has any magical powers related to money, nor do we have any indication that magic is even remotely associated with protections for the tithe paying. The only thing we know is that the tithe paying is a superstition that Nautilus remembers, and he associates the payment of the tithe with not being consumed by the waters. There are gaps to fill in, yes, but that would imply there's a lot of magic at work that we haven't even seen or gotten hints of. All we know is that something consumed him, and that's it. We don't know it's nature, and we don't get an impression of crazy magics around it.

I would be lying if I said I am not disappointed that Nautilus is no longer a monstrous thing on the hunt for revenge, but I suppose with Pyke's story and many others it would have been far too similar to keep intact. Still, I do greatly enjoy the direction they took him. Nautilus has become a thing of legend and tale, a terrible undersea wrath that destroys those who do not pay the tithe to the great ocean. I like that, and I like it a lot. A few questions if anyone on the lore team is reading this:
1. Is Nautilus still attempting to keep an eye out for his former captain, if he ever did see him again?
2. Is the lore about Nautilus holding off the a part of the Harrowing all by himself still canon, and if so does this imply that deep down Nautilus still has the compassion of a human, however buried it may be? (This is the one I am most interested in)
3. Does Nautilus even vaguely know of the affairs of Bilgewater? Does he even remember Bilgewater at all? If he does in any respect, what do you think his feelings regarding our current cast of characters would be? Theoretically of course.
The lore team has done a fine job with my favorite champion in the League so far, and I look forward to what they do in the future with him.
I hope they keep the harrowing part canon, it is by far my favorite piece of lore in League of Legends.

You're acting like they are. They literally had to take an existing champions lore just to make something "new." Idk why you're so opposed to people stating exactly what is happening. Not everyone is as optimistic as you and this was literally a day ago.

They explained that this was due to the fact that the lore of Nautilus was gonna be changed and even now,the 2 might have a similar origin,but the execution is wildly different(Pyke is out for revenge and his obsession with it drove him mad,Naut was denied his revenge and moved on).

Anyway if that is what you criticize here,then you need to keep in mind that they did this already once back in the old days,where both Shaco and Evelynn were killers for hire with a mysterious past.

I love the new lore, I feel like it added a lot while preserving what themes the old lore had. However, it misses one big thing, and arguably his most defining feature: His anchor.

The whole point of the anchor in his old lore was that it was his only clue and hope towards finding those who betrayed him, and instead of putting his anchor down and leaving his grudge behind him he carried it with him. This story doesn't really even touch on that, and it almost comes as a surprise that he still has the anchor at the end, since it barely talked about him carrying it before. Instead of talking about the most important part about the champion, it keeps talking about the tithe thing for some reason. It would be like if Braum's lore barely talked about his door-shield and then randomly mentions at the end that he uses a door as a weapon.


Other than that, I like what they did with the new Nautilus, and the idea of him working with a salvage crew, as well as the fact that he normally freedived instead of being clad in armor. That aspect is definitely better than the researcher for the League thing he had in his old lore.

Actually, his anchor was mentioned: "Nautilus grabbed the anchor chain, his last connection to the world above, and hauled himself up even as the thing below sought to drag him down. But the weight was too much. Just as his giant metal fingers were about to breach the surface, the chain snapped. Nautilus screamed within the suit, but none could hear him. He tumbled back into the inky maelstrom, clutching the sinking anchor in desperation. Dark tendrils enveloped him, and he could only watch as the dimming outline of his ship faded away. Then everything went black."  So it's still a memento from his betrayal and something that sunk into the darkness with him!

Yes, it mentions the anchor, but it doesn't talk about why he continues to carry it. In fact, it doesn't even mention whether he takes that same anchor on his trip back to shore. For all we know from this story it could be some random anchor he found once he got back to port.

The story couldn't exactly mention him carrying it before the incident as it was still attached to the ship, and the story only covers up to his transformation and a bit general afterwards.  Old Naut lore still had it so that finding his old crew was possible, but new Naut lore had him under for so long the crew and captain had disappeared.  Also it mentions 'his' anchor at the end, not 'an' anchor, meaning most likely it is the one that fell with him.
